title: Blessing a Church Remade
content: [nytmedia id="100000003936249" crop="592" type="image"] At the conclusion of the vespers service came a special New York moment: the pope's blessing of St. Patrick's Cathedral, the 19th century edifice now gleaming after a three-year, $177 million renovation. A beaming Cardinal Dolan lent the proceedings his signature gusto. "Papa Francesco," he said broadly in Italian, drawing applause. "Welcome to St. Patrick's Cathedral!" "Once you entered those famous doors on Fifth Avenue, you become an official New Yorker, but you already had a home in our hearts and souls," Cardinal Dolan told the pope, who smiled, seeming pleased but also somehow inscrutable. Then Cardinal Dolan thanked the workers who had renewed the cathedral, who had been given tickets to stand outside and greet the pope. And he thanked the generous donors who were given tickets to be inside. Then the ever-folksy Cardinal said, "Thank you for stopping by, and come back soon," to applause and laughter from the crowd. He enveloped the pope in a warm embrace. A microphone was brought over to Pope Francis. The contrast between the two men's styles was dramatic, the pope delivering his blessing quietly and calmly, his English unsteady. "Lord, bless this church, which we have been privileged to build with your help," he said."May all who gather here in faith to listen to your word, and celebrate your sacraments, experience the presence of Christ, who promised to be with those gathered in his name, for he lives and reigns with you and the Holy Spirit, one God, for ever and ever." Amen, the crowd responded.

title: Francis Thanks America’s Nuns and Receives a Standing Ovation
content: [nytmedia id="100000003936208" crop="592" type="image"] Only one section in the pope's homily at St. Patrick's drew applause: his special thank you to America's nuns. "In a special way I would like to express my esteem and gratitude to the religious women of the United States," he said, in remarks delivered in Spanish and translated into English on video screens around the soaring nave. "What would the Church be without you? Women of strength, fighters, with that spirit of courage which puts you in the front lines in the proclamation of the Gospel." Francis, who has worked to put an end to tensions between the Vatican and American nuns, continued: "To you, religious women, sisters and mothers of this people, I wish to say thank you, a big thank you. And to tell you that I love you very much." Three times the crowd of thousands applauded loudly, finally getting to their feet as he thanked the nuns for their hard work. And then the homily was over, and the room stood again to applaud.

title: Pope Laments the Wages of Materialism
content:
Another danger comes when we become jealous of our free time, when we think that surrounding ourselves with worldly comforts will help us serve better. The problem with this reasoning is that it can blunt the power of God’s daily call to conversion, to encounter with him.
In his homily to clergy members, nuns and members of religious orders at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Pope Francis reminds them that they should live simply. This is a common criticism of the church hierarchy in many American dioceses, including in New York, where Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan lives in a Madison Avenue mansion attached to the cathedral instead of in simpler quarters.

title: Francis Criticizes Church’s Businesslike Approach
content:
We can get caught up measuring the value of our apostolic works by the standards of efficiency, good management and outward success which govern the business world.
Pope Francis is warning clergy members, nuns and brothers that taking a business-inspired approach to their ministries can dampen their spirit of “generous self-sacrifice.” The Archdiocese of New York has been going through a reorganization that has resulted in the closing of nearly 40 churches, and some have criticized the closures for being motivated by business rather than pastoral priorities. The pope's comment will likely be welcomed by those critics.

title: Pope Again Sympathizes With Church Leaders over Abuse Fallout
content:
I know that, as a presbyterate in the midst of God's people, you suffered greatly in the not distant past by having to bear the shame of some of your brothers who harmed and scandalized the Church in the most vulnerable of her members... In the words of the Book of Revelation, I know well that you 'have come forth from the great tribulation.' I accompany you at this time of pain and difficulty, and I thank God for your faithful service to his people.
In the remarks he is delivering at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Francis is echoing the remarks he made on the church's abuse scandals on Wednesday, when he told American bishops that he "supported your generous commitment to bring healing to victims – in the knowledge that in healing we, too, are healed – and to work to ensure that such crimes will never be repeated." He also praised them for their "courage" and the "great sacrifice" they had made. Advocates for the victims of sexual abuse by priests have condemned his words. They also questioned why Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, the former archbishop of Los Angeles who was relieved of ministry duties over revelations that he had covered up for abusive priests, was traveling with Francis. "Once again, he seems to be talking about the pain and embarrassment of the bishops, as opposed to the pain and embarrassment of the victims, who've been raped and sodomized," said Barbara Dorris, the victims outreach director of the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests. "Well, they created this crisis by protecting predators; children didn't ask to be raped. So to compare the two things is grossly unjust."

title: Joyous Applause
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003936130" crop="592" type="image"]
At exactly 6:45 p.m. the choir and organ in St. Patrick's Cathedral erupted into song. Nuns clambered onto pews holding up their cellphones. The pope, after hours and days and weeks of anticipation, was here!

He walked through the door, and sprinkled holy water toward the crowd. The applause was joyous. And then he plunged down the aisle, a diminutive figure in front of the boisterous Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, lost in the sea of people who rushed through the side aisles to greet him.

He shook hands with those in the front rows of the pews, and blessed a young girl in a wheelchair, who started sobbing. Then he knelt before the eucharist and went to change into his green and gold vestments, the tall miter making him seem even smaller and more humble.

As the service began, he sat on the side of the altar, a serious face, joining with the other priests in prayer.

title: Francis 1, Donald 0
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003936105" crop="592" type="image"]

While a crowd of tens of thousands gathered to await the pope's arrival at St. Patrick's Cathedral, one of the city's best-known residents kept popping up and causing a stir.

Donald J. Trump walked out the golden doors of the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue around 4:30 p.m. and into the crowd that had gathered to see the pope. The real estate mogul and presidential candidate waved and grinned, and was initially greeted with cheers. But they quickly turned to boos.

Around 6:15 p.m. Mr. Trump reappeared, this time higher up, on a  balcony above the Gucci store. Dressed in a navy sport jacket, a white shirt and a blue striped tie,  he waved down to the crowd, which was largely Hispanic. This time, the jeering became even louder.

Mr. Trump retreated inside only to return again. This time the crowd began to chant, "Feo! Feo!"  -- a Spanish word for "ugly."

One of those chanting was Patricia Delgado, who is from Ecuador and lives in Queens.

"I don't like Donald Trump," she said. "In fact I hate Donald Trump."

In response to the jeers, Mr. Trump waved more, smiled and gave the crowd a thumbs-up.

Carlos Delgado, Ms. Delgado's husband, also from Ecuador, was silent.

"I'm here for the pope of love," he said. "I've had enough of Donald Trump."
